pib 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

    Compute bounds from estimated components.

    post_instrument_bounds.Rd

    Compute bounds from estimated components.

    Usage

    post_instrument_bounds(
  gamma,
  sigma = 0,
  n.sigma = 5,
  estimates,
  df,
  outcome,
  post.inst,
  whichCI = "percentile",
  remove.outliers = T,
  conf = 0.95
)

    Arguments

    gamma

    Integer or vector of integers giving lowest and highest value for mean causal effect of post-instrument variable M on outcome Y

    sigma

    Integer or vector of integers giving lowest and highest value for variance of causal effect of M on Y. Must be non-negative. Defaults to zero.

    n.sigma

    Integer: Number of distinct values of sigma (within bounds provided by sigma argument) for which to compute bounds. Defaults to 5.

    estimates

    An object from calling estimate_sensitivity() that contains a vector of point estimates t as well as bootstrap replicates t0

    df

    Data frame

    outcome

    Name of dependent variables of interest Y, a string

    post.inst

    Name of post-instrument variable M, a string

    whichCI

    Determines the type of boostrap confidence interval: percentile (the default), basic, or both

    remove.outliers

    Logical. If TRUE (the default), outliers from bootstrapped sampling distribution of the 2SLS regressions for Y and M are removed. The resulting sampling distribution should better approximate results from standard robust standard errors.

    conf

    The confidence level of the confidence intervals. Defaults to 0.95

    Value

    A matrix with values of gamma, sigma, point estimates or bounds of treatment effect, and confidence intervals for those point estimates or bounds.

    Details

    The function assumes that the instrument Z, treatment D, and post-instrument variable M are binary (in which case there is only the sensitivity parameter gamma and sigma can be left at its default value zero), or that z is binary and D and M continuous, in which case both gamma and sigma are sensitivity parameters.

    References

    Schuessler, J., Glynn, A. N., & Rueda, M.R. (2023). Post-Instrument Bias.

    Glynn, A. N., Rueda, M. R., & Schuessler, J. (2023). Post-Instrument Bias in Linear Models. Sociological Methods & Research.

    Examples

    if (FALSE) {
gamma <- c(-0.02, 0.02)
sigma <- c(0, 0.002)
bounds <- post.instrument.bounds(gamma = gamma, sigma = sigma,
n.sigma = 2, estimates = out)}
